nexttext:
where  {{$\mu(.)$}} is the hasard rate function, also called \textit{force of mortality}.\\ 

Several parametric mortality laws such as De Moivre, constant force of mortality, Gompertz, Inverse-Gompertz, Makeham, Gamma, Lognormal and Weibull are used in the literature; see \cite{bowers1986actuarial}. The choice of a specific mortality model is determined mainly by the caracteristics of the available data and the objective of the study. It is well known that the De Moivre law and the constant force of mortality assumptions are interesting for {{theoretical}} purposes whereas Gompertz and Weibull are more appropriate for fitting real data, {{especially for population of age over $30$}}. 

{{The {{data set }} exploited in this paper   regroups essentially policyholders who are at least middle-aged.     }}
 That is why, in our study, the interest is on the Gompertz law whose caracteristics are defined as follows

prevtext:
where  {{$\mu(.)$}} is the hasard rate function, also called \textit{force of mortality}.\\ 

Several parametric mortality laws such as De Moivre, constant force of mortality, Gompertz, Inverse-Gompertz, Makeham, Gamma, Lognormal and Weibull are used in the literature; see \cite{bowers1986actuarial}. The choice of a specific mortality model is determined mainly by the caracteristics of the available data and the objective of the study. It is well known that the De Moivre law and the constant force of mortality assumptions are interesting for {{theoretical}} purposes whereas Gompertz and Weibull are more appropriate for fitting real data, {{especially for population of age over $30$}}. 

{{The {{data set }} exploited in this paper   regroups essentially policyholders who are at least middle-aged.     }}
 That is why, in our study, the interest is on the Gompertz law whose caracteristics are defined as follows

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex3.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\mu\left(x\right)=Bc^{x}\;\;\;\;\;\text{ and }\;\;\;\;\;S\left(x\right)=\exp%
\left(-\frac{B}{\ln c}\left(c^{x}-1\right)\right)\;\;\;\;\;\text{ with }\;\;\;%
\;\;B>0,\;\;c>1,\;\;x\geq 0." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>μ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>B</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>c</mi><mi>x</mi></msup></mrow><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true">  </mo><mtext> and </mtext></mrow></mrow><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true">  </mo><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>S</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>exp</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mfrac><mi>B</mi><mrow><mi>ln</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>c</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><msup><mi>c</mi><mi>x</mi></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true">  </mo><mtext> with </mtext></mrow></mrow><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true">  </mo><mrow><mrow><mi>B</mi><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mo rspace="8.1pt">,</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>c</mi><mo>></mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo rspace="8.1pt">,</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>≥</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

/\sigma}=c" display="block"><mrow><mrow><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>m</mi><mo>/</mo><mi>σ</mi></mrow></mrow></msup><mo>=</mo><mrow><mfrac><mi>B</mi><mrow><mi>ln</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>c</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true">   </mo><mtext> and </mtext></mrow></mrow><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true">   </mo><mrow><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>/</mo><mi>σ</mi></mrow></msup><mo>=</mo><mi>c</mi></mrow></mrow></math>

Product 2 is the last survivor annuity which pays a certain amount until the time of the second death $T\left( \overline{xy}\right)$. In that case, the present value of {{ future}} annuities and its expectation are given by

\right)}{\delta}\;\;\;\;\;\;\text{ and }\;\;\;\;\;\;\bar{a}_{xy}=\mathbb{E}%
\left(\bar{a}_{{#1}{T\left(xy\right)}}\right)" display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>a</mi><mo stretchy="false">¯</mo></mover><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">#</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>T</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>exp</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>T</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mi>δ</mi></mfrac><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true">   </mo><mtext> and </mtext></mrow></mrow><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true">   </mo><mrow><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>a</mi><mo stretchy="false">¯</mo></mover><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi>𝔼</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>a</mi><mo stretchy="false">¯</mo></mover><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">#</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>T</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></msub><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext: In practice, payments often start at a higher level when both beneficiaries are alive. It drops at a lower level on the death of either and continues until the death of the survivor. This case is emphasized by product 3 where the rate is 1 when both annuitant are alive and reduces to $\frac{2}{3}$ after the first death. Product 3 is actually a combination of the two first annuities. Thus, the insurer {{ liabilities}} and its expectation are given by
prevtext: where $\delta$ is the constant instantaneous interest rate (also called force of interest). The variable $\bar{a}_{{#1}{T\left( xy\right)}}$ can be seen as the insurer liability regarding $\left( xy\right) $. Product 2 is the last survivor annuity which pays a certain amount until the time of the second death $T\left( \overline{xy}\right)$. In that case, the present value of {{ future}} annuities and its expectation are given by

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex29.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\bar{a}_{{#1}{T\left(\overline{xy}\right)}}=\frac{1-\exp\left(-\delta T\left(%
\overline{xy}\right)\right)}{\delta}\;\;\;\;\;\;\text{ and }\;\;\;\;\;\;\bar{a%
}_{\overline{xy}}=\mathbb{E}\left(\bar{a}_{{#1}{T\left(\overline{xy}\right)}}\right)" display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>a</mi><mo stretchy="false">¯</mo></mover><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">#</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>T</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mover accent="true"><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mo>¯</mo></mover><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>exp</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>T</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mover accent="true"><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mo>¯</mo></mover><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mi>δ</mi></mfrac><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true">   </mo><mtext> and </mtext></mrow></mrow><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true">   </mo><mrow><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>a</mi><mo stretchy="false">¯</mo></mover><mover accent="true"><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mo>¯</mo></mover></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi>𝔼</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>a</mi><mo stretchy="false">¯</mo></mover><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">#</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>T</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mover accent="true"><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mo>¯</mo></mover><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></msub><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext:
where $\mathbb{E}\left( \bar{a}_{{#1}{T\left( \overline{xy}\right)}} \right)= \bar{a}_{\overline{xy}}$.
\\Fourthly, imagine a family or couple whose income is mainly funded by the husband. The family may want to guarantee its source of income for the eventual death of the husband. For this purpose, the couple may buy the so called \textit{reversionary annuity} for which the payments start right after the death of $\left( x\right) $ until the death of $\left( y\right) $. No payment is made if $\left( y\right) $ dies before $\left( x\right) $. As for Product 3, the reversionary annuity (Product 4) is also  a combination of some specific annuity policies and the total {{obligations}} {{of the insurer}} and its expectation are computed {{as follows}}
prevtext: In practice, payments often start at a higher level when both beneficiaries are alive. It drops at a lower level on the death of either and continues until the death of the survivor. This case is emphasized by product 3 where the rate is 1 when both annuitant are alive and reduces to $\frac{2}{3}$ after the first death. Product 3 is actually a combination of the two first annuities. Thus, the insurer {{ liabilities}} and its expectation are given by
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex30.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="V\left(\overline{xy}\right)=\frac{1}{3}\bar{a}_{{#1}{T\left(xy\right)}}+\frac{%
2}{3}\bar{a}_{{#1}{T\left(\overline{xy}\right)}}\;\;\;\;\;\text{ and }\;\;\;\;%
\;\mathbb{E}\left(V\left(\overline{xy}\right)\right)=V_{\overline{xy}}=\frac{1%
}{3}\bar{a}_{xy}+\frac{2}{3}\bar{a}_{\overline{xy}}" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>V</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mover accent="true"><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mo>¯</mo></mover><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>a</mi><mo stretchy="false">¯</mo></mover><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">#</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>T</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></msub></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>a</mi><mo stretchy="false">¯</mo></mover><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">#</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>T</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mover accent="true"><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mo>¯</mo></mover><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true">  </mo><mtext> and </mtext></mrow></mrow><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true">  </mo><mrow><mrow><mi>𝔼</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mi>V</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mover accent="true"><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mo>¯</mo></mover><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mover accent="true"><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mo>¯</mo></mover></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>a</mi><mo stretchy="false">¯</mo></mover><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow></msub></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>a</mi><mo stretchy="false">¯</mo></mover><mover accent="true"><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mo>¯</mo></mover></msub></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

For this purpose, the couple may buy the so called \textit{reversionary annuity} for which the payments start right after the death of $\left( x\right) $ until the death of $\left( y\right) $. No payment is made if $\left( y\right) $ dies before $\left( x\right) $.
